questions.article: Whether the reign of a French monarch such as Francis II or Louis XI was considered historically significant or, conversely, relatively ______, its trajectory was shaped by questions of legitimacy and therefore cannot be understood without a corollary understanding of the factors that allowed the monarch to assert a claim to the throne successfully.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

options.name: A
options.content: momentous

options.name: B
options.content: inconsequential

options.name: C
options.content: benevolent

options.name: D
options.content: genuine

questions.correct: inconsequential

questions.article: In the 2010s, the price of vintage Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles action figures rose dramatically, which had the counterintuitive effect of ______ demand: buyers who hadn't previously wanted to purchase old action figures thronged the market, believing prices would continue to rise and the toys could be resold later at a profit.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

options.name: A
options.content: monetizing

options.name: B
options.content: appraising

options.name: C
options.content: engendering

options.name: D
options.content: exploiting

questions.correct: engendering

questions.article: Studying wrappers from discontinued candies, menus from nineteenth-century restaurants, and flyers promoting long-forgotten sporting events may seem like a frivolous pursuit, but ephemeral objects like these are useful as markers of cultural change: they can ______ shifts in norms, values, and concerns that traditional objects of historical inquiry may not.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

options.name: A
options.content: register

options.name: B
options.content: vindicate

options.name: C
options.content: preclude

options.name: D
options.content: induce

questions.correct: register

questions.article: ______ though it seemed to many mathematicians, the Marden tameness conjecture, posed in 1974, eventually yielded to the efforts of Ian Agol, who presented a proof of it in 2004.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical and precise word or phrase?

options.name: A
options.content: Insuperable

options.name: B
options.content: Unequivocal

options.name: C
options.content: Irreproachable

options.name: D
options.content: Ineluctable

questions.correct: Insuperable

questions.article: Why do rusty-spotted cats purr but jaguars roar? Researchers hypothesize that this difference between the two feline species may be partly due to a U-shaped bone in their throats called the hyoid. Rusty-spotted cats, which are much smaller than jaguars, have a rigid hyoid that rumbles when the cat's larynx vibrates, resulting in a purr. By contrast, jaguars have a somewhat flexible hyoid, and the bone is attached to the skull with a stretchy ligament that rusty-spotted cats lack. These traits allow jaguars and most other species of big cats to produce powerful roars. The same traits may also prevent most big cats from purring.
questions.question: Which choice best describes the overall structure of the text?

options.name: A
options.content: The text compares the habitats of two species, then explains how those habitats are changing.

options.name: B
options.content: The text presents a theory about two species, then discusses facts that weaken it.

options.name: C
options.content: The text poses a question about two species, then presents a possible answer.

options.name: D
options.content: The text describes a behavior shared by two species, then discusses other behaviors shared by them.

questions.correct: The text poses a question about two species, then presents a possible answer.

questions.article: Scholarly interest in literary juvenilia—writings by children and teenagers—tends to focus on unpublished works by authors who became famous as adults, such as Charles Dickens's poem "The Bill of Fare," which he wrote around the ages of 18-20, because they offer insights into their authors' artistic development. But some scholars also argue that recovering juvenilia by lesser-known writers is essential to understanding literary history: Daisy Ashford's novels, which she published as a child, were widely read by contemporaries and are therefore deserving of closer attention.
questions.question: Which choice best states the main purpose of the text?

options.name: A
options.content: To describe the challenges famous writers encountered when seeking to publish works written in their childhood.

options.name: B
options.content: To present reasons why literary scholars consider juvenilia to be valuable resources.

options.name: C
options.content: To compare the accomplishments of young writers with those of their adult contemporaries.

options.name: D
options.content: To argue that Ashford's novels have more literary merit than Dickens's juvenilia do.

questions.correct: To present reasons why literary scholars consider juvenilia to be valuable resources.

questions.article: To understand how temperature change affects microorganism-mediated cycling of soil nutrients in alpine ecosystems, Eva Kastovska et al. collected plant-soil cores in the Tatra Mountains at elevations around 2,100 meters and transplanted them to elevations of 1,700-1,800 meters, where the mean air temperature was warmer by 2°C. Microorganism-mediated nutrient cycling was accelerated in the transplanted cores; crucially, microorganism community composition was unchanged, allowing Kastovska et al. to attribute the acceleration to temperature-induced increases in microorganism activity.
questions.question: It can most reasonably be inferred from the text that the finding about the microorganism community composition was important for which reason?

options.name: A
options.content: It provided preliminary evidence that microorganism-mediated nutrient cycling was accelerated in the transplanted cores.

options.name: B
options.content: It suggested that temperature-induced changes in microorganism activity may be occurring at increasingly high elevations.

options.name: C
options.content: It ruled out a potential alternative explanation for the acceleration in microorganism-mediated nutrient cycling.

options.name: D
options.content: It clarified that microorganism activity levels in the plant-soil cores varied depending on which microorganisms comprised the community.

questions.correct: It ruled out a potential alternative explanation for the acceleration in microorganism-mediated nutrient cycling.

questions.article: Michael G. Campana and colleagues relied on historical DNA (hDNA)—genomic data incidentally preserved in specimens housed in natural history collections—to investigate the evolutionary origins of a fungal pathogen affecting bats. Although this approach offers unique benefits, such as access to genomic data from extirpated populations, it remains a relatively underutilized resource because hDNA is often to some extent degraded, a situation not easily remediable under current methodological paradigms and with extant DNA extraction and analysis technologies.
questions.question: Information in the text best supports which statement about hDNA?

options.name: A
options.content: It may yield insights that other types of genomic data cannot.

options.name: B
options.content: It has thus far proved valuable mainly to researchers studying pathogens.

options.name: C
options.content: It may be underused because of its controversial status among scientists.

options.name: D
options.content: It tends to be much more degraded than other types of DNA of comparable age.

questions.correct: It may yield insights that other types of genomic data cannot.

questions.article: In a paper for an art history class, a student claims that Rosa Bonheur's 1855 painting The Horse Fair marks a significant change in Bonheur's artistic development.
questions.question: Which quotation from an art history textbook would most effectively support the student's claim?

options.name: A
options.content: "The paintings that Bonheur produced before The Horse Fair can be thought of as belonging to her earlier style, to which she never returned."

options.name: B
options.content: "Of all Bonheur's paintings, none so clearly represents her abilities and ideas as The Horse Fair."

options.name: C
options.content: "The Horse Fair has been analyzed extensively since it was first exhibited, as no two viewers seem to agree about exactly what the painting means."

options.name: D
options.content: "Although Bonheur was clearly influenced by other artists of her time, she was also an artist ahead of her time, as The Horse Fair demonstrates."

questions.correct: "The paintings that Bonheur produced before The Horse Fair can be thought of as belonging to her earlier style, to which she never returned."

questions.article: Neurobiologists Laura Cuaya, Raul Hernandez-Perez, and colleagues investigated the language detection abilities of eighteen dogs. The researchers monitored the brain activity of Kun-kun (a border collie), Bingo (a mixed breed), and other dogs while the animals listened to three recordings: one of The Little Prince being read in Spanish, the second in Hungarian, and a third made up of short, randomly selected fragments of the first two, scrambled so that they didn't resemble human speech. Each dog was familiar with either Spanish or Hungarian, but not both. The team concluded that differences in dogs’ anatomical features may affect their ability to distinguish speech from nonspeech.
questions.question: Which finding from the study, if true, would most directly support the team's conclusion?

options.name: A
options.content: Compared with longer-headed dogs, shorter-headed dogs showed less difference in brain activity when hearing either Spanish or Hungarian than when hearing the scrambled recording.

options.name: B
options.content: Compared with longer-headed dogs, shorter-headed dogs showed a greater difference in brain activity when hearing the language they were accustomed to than when hearing the other language.

options.name: C
options.content: The pattern of brain activity that long-headed dogs showed when hearing the scrambled recording was different from the pattern of brain activity that short-headed dogs showed when hearing the language they were accustomed to.

options.name: D
options.content: Long-headed dogs accustomed to hearing Spanish tended to show more brain activity when hearing Spanish than long-headed dogs accustomed to hearing Hungarian showed when hearing Hungarian.

questions.correct: Compared with longer-headed dogs, shorter-headed dogs showed less difference in brain activity when hearing either Spanish or Hungarian than when hearing the scrambled recording.

questions.article: “Poetry” is a 1919 poem by Marianne Moore. The poem highlights an ambivalence toward poetry as the speaker acknowledges its merits while also expressing a sense of displeasure, writing ______
questions.question: Which quotation from “Poetry” most effectively illustrates the claim?

options.name: A
options.content: “nor is it valid / to discriminate against business documents and / school-books'; all these phenomena are important.”

options.name: B
options.content: “One must make a distinction / however: when dragged into prominence by half poets, the result is not / poetry”

options.name: C
options.content: “when [poems] become so derivative as to become unintelligible, the / same thing may be said for all of us that we / do not admire what / we cannot understand”

options.name: D
options.content: “Reading [poetry], however, with a perfect contempt for it, one discovers that there is in / it after all, a place for the genuine.”

questions.correct: “Reading [poetry], however, with a perfect contempt for it, one discovers that there is in / it after all, a place for the genuine.”

questions.article: Cane is a 1923 novel by Jean Toomer. In one portion of the novel, Toomer uses figurative language to connect the narrator's urban environment of Washington, DC, and the rural South of the narrator's past, writing, ______
questions.question: Which quotation from Cane most effectively illustrates the claim?

options.name: A
options.content: “The [train] engines of this valley have a whistle, the echoes of which sound like iterated gasps and sobs. I always think of them as crude music.”

options.name: B
options.content: “I sang, with a strange quiver in my voice, a promise-song.”

options.name: C
options.content: “The young trees had not outgrown their [planter] boxes then. V Street [in Washington, DC] was lined with them.”

options.name: D
options.content: “And when the wind is from the South, soil of my homeland falls like a fertile shower upon the lean streets of [Washington, DC].”

questions.correct: “And when the wind is from the South, soil of my homeland falls like a fertile shower upon the lean streets of [Washington, DC].”

questions.article: Some climate models for the western United States predict that while total annual precipitation may remain unchanged from the present level, precipitation will become concentrated into fewer but more intense rain and snow events. University of Texas climate scientist Geeta Persad and her colleagues simulated how the amount of water entering aquifers and the amount being used for irrigation purposes would change if this were to occur. Persad and her colleagues concluded that concentration of precipitation into fewer events would result in a higher number of dry days, triggering more irrigation, but that this change in irrigation output is highly sensitive to the baseline concentration of precipitation that currently exists in an area.
questions.question: Which choice best describes data from the table that support Persad and her colleagues' conclusion?

options.name: A
options.content: If baseline precipitation is somewhat concentrated, the amount of water being used for irrigation will increase 0.4% for surface water and 0.9% for groundwater, whereas the amount of water entering aquifers will increase 11.0% if baseline precipitation is evenly distributed.

options.name: B
options.content: If baseline precipitation is somewhat concentrated, water use for irrigation will increase only slightly, whereas it will increase 9.0% for surface water and 7.9% for groundwater if baseline precipitation is evenly distributed.

options.name: C
options.content: If baseline precipitation is somewhat concentrated, the amount of water entering aquifers will increase 4.9%, while the amount being used for irrigation will increase 0.4% for surface water and 0.9% for groundwater.

options.name: D
options.content: If baseline precipitation is somewhat concentrated, water use for irrigation will decline by a small amount, whereas it will increase 11.0% for surface water and 9.0% for groundwater if baseline precipitation is evenly distributed.

questions.correct: If baseline precipitation is somewhat concentrated, water use for irrigation will increase only slightly, whereas it will increase 9.0% for surface water and 7.9% for groundwater if baseline precipitation is evenly distributed.

questions.article: Ships in the British Royal Navy during the Napoleonic Wars (1803–1815) were ranked based on military strength. The system considered the number of a ship's cannons and decks. “First-rate” was the highest ranking, and “sixth-rate” was the lowest ranking, followed by unranked ships. The size of a ship's crew was based on this ranking: first-rate ships had between 850 and 875 crewmen, while lower-ranked ships had fewer. Two of the ships in the British Royal Navy from this period were the Boyne (98 cannons and three decks) and the Britannia (120 cannons and three decks). Of these two, only the Britannia was ranked a first-rate ship. It can therefore be concluded that
questions.question: Which choice most logically completes the text?

options.name: A
options.content: some ships with three decks had a crew of fewer than 850 people.

options.name: B
options.content: the Britannia needed a crew larger than 875 people in order to operate efficiently.

options.name: C
options.content: the Boyne had a larger crew than the Britannia.

options.name: D
options.content: all ships with at least 98 cannons had a crew of at least 850 people.

questions.correct: some ships with three decks had a crew of fewer than 850 people.

questions.article: In a 2018 study, Deepak Jaiswal and Rishi Kant found that consumers' knowledge of environmental issues had no effect on the likelihood that the consumers would purchase environmentally friendly products. Since this study was based on fewer than 400 young adults in India, however, doubts have been raised about how reliable and representative the findings are. To better understand the issue, Wencan Zhuang and colleagues analyzed the results of 54 studies of eco-friendly consumer behavior, such as a 2018 study from Indonesia that included 916 participants and a 2018 study from India with 202 participants. Taking all 54 studies together, Zhuang and colleagues found a significant positive effect of environmental knowledge on eco-friendly purchasing decisions, suggesting that ______
questions.question: Which choice most logically completes the text?

options.name: A
options.content: a sample size of 202 may be sufficient to make reliable conclusions about the relationship between knowledge of environmental issues and purchasing decisions.

options.name: B
options.content: concerns about the broad applicability of Jaiswal and Kant's conclusion were justified.

options.name: C
options.content: the number of participants in Jaiswal and Kant's study was far below the number of participants in most studies of purchasing decisions.

options.name: D
options.content: Jaiswal and Kant's methodology was more precise than the methodology used in the 2018 study from Indonesia.

questions.correct: concerns about the broad applicability of Jaiswal and Kant's conclusion were justified.

questions.article: In Norway, the Longyearbyen observatory site monitors activity in the upper atmosphere of the northern ______ in Australia, another observatory site, Buckland Park, monitors the sky of the southern hemisphere. Together, they are part of the Super Dual Auroral Radar Network—or SuperDARN, as space physicists like Tadahiko Ogawa call it.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: hemisphere and

options.name: B
options.content: hemisphere

options.name: C
options.content: hemisphere,

options.name: D
options.content: hemisphere;

questions.correct: hemisphere;

questions.article: Long attributed to Jacques-Louis David, the preeminent Neoclassical painter of his day, the 1801 painting Marie Josephine Charlotte du Val d'Ognes gained fresh attention in the 1990s when art historians discovered that the painting, which depicts a solitary young woman sketching, was actually the work of little-known French portrait ______ Marie-Denise Villers (1774–1821).
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: artist—

options.name: B
options.content: artist

options.name: C
options.content: artist:

options.name: D
options.content: artist,

questions.correct: artist

questions.article: Along the hallowed walls of New York City's Museum of Modern Art hangs 24.5-by-34.5 inch oil ______ which was created in 1964 by American artist Vija Celmins.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: painting Gun with Hand #1

options.name: B
options.content: painting, Gun with Hand #1,

options.name: C
options.content: painting Gun with Hand #1,

options.name: D
options.content: painting, Gun with Hand #1

questions.correct: painting Gun with Hand #1,

questions.article: Legal scholars James Melton and Tom Ginsburg's analysis of de jure judicial independence and its growth over decades ______ six constitutional features that enhance such independence, including judicial tenure and selection procedure. Romania's constitution contains one of these features.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: have identified

options.name: B
options.content: identifies

options.name: C
options.content: are identifying

options.name: D
options.content: identify

questions.correct: identifies

questions.article: For Spain, a member of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO) since 1982, NATO's principle of collective defense confers both benefits and ______ organization's many members, nations as disparate as the US and Slovenia, are all bound to defend Spain, the reverse is also true.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: obligations; the

options.name: B
options.content: obligations. The

options.name: C
options.content: obligations, while the

options.name: D
options.content: obligations: while the

questions.correct: obligations: while the

questions.article: As of 2017, Italy's top tax rate of 55% was lower than the country's Laffer curve peak (70%). To some economists, whether a tax cut will ultimately increase Italy's tax revenue is dependent on the country's position on the Laffer ______ a theoretical relationship between tax rates and revenues, the curve was famously sketched on a napkin by economist Arthur Laffer in 1974.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text so that it conforms to the conventions of Standard English?

options.name: A
options.content: curve

options.name: B
options.content: curve;

options.name: C
options.content: curve, which is

options.name: D
options.content: curve,

questions.correct: curve;

questions.article: Working together with the Navajo Nation Department of Water Resources, Dr. Lani Tsinnajinnie analyzed data about snowpack levels in the Chuska Mountains. She found that the snowpack (the amount of snow on the ground) was deepest in early March at lower elevations. At higher elevations, ______ the snowpack was deepest in mid-March.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?

options.name: A
options.content: in other words,

options.name: B
options.content: for instance,

options.name: C
options.content: on the other hand,

options.name: D
options.content: in summary,

questions.correct: on the other hand,

questions.article: Biographer Michael Gorra notes that the novelist Henry James "lived in a world of second thoughts," frequently tinkering with his novels and stories after their initial publication. However, the differences between the 1881 first edition and the 1908 edition of his novel A Portrait of a Lady are extreme, even by James's standards; ______ some critics regard the two editions as two different novels altogether.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?

options.name: A
options.content: by contrast,

options.name: B
options.content: in fact,

options.name: C
options.content: nevertheless,

options.name: D
options.content: in other words,

questions.correct: in fact,

questions.article: Scientists studying asteroid deflection have focused on secondary objects such as S/2020(2013 PY6), a moonlet orbiting the near-Earth asteroid 2013 PY6. In 2022 NASA intentionally crashed a probe into just such an object, successfully altering its orbit. Scientists have yet to demonstrate, ______ that 2013 PY6 and other primary objects would be similarly affected.
questions.question: Which choice completes the text with the most logical transition?

options.name: A
options.content: for example,

options.name: B
options.content: though,

options.name: C
options.content: likewise,

options.name: D
options.content: moreover,

questions.correct: though,

questions.article:
While researching a topic, a student has taken the following notes:

  • Documentary TV programs in the slow TV genre consist of uninterrupted broadcasts of ordinary events in real time.
  • Nordlandsbanen: Minutt for Minutt is a Norwegian slow TV program.
  • The 10-hour-long program documented a train ride from Trondheim to Bodo.
  • It first aired in 2012.
  • In her book Spectacular Television: Exploring Televisual Pleasure, British film scholar Helen Wheatley writes that slow TV “offers unspectacular' spectacle.”
questions.question: The student wants to provide a specific example of a slow TV program. Which choice most effectively uses relevant information from the notes to accomplish this goal?

options.name: A
options.content: British film scholar Helen Wheatley writes about the slow TV genre in her book Spectacular Television: Exploring Televisual Pleasure.

options.name: B
options.content: An example of the slow TV genre can be seen in Nordlandsbanen: Minutt for Minutt, a 2012 Norwegian show featuring an uninterrupted 10-hour real-time broadcast of a train ride from Trondheim to Bodo.

options.name: C
options.content: Slow TV programs provide uninterrupted broadcasts of ordinary events, such as train rides, in real time.

options.name: D
options.content: With their uninterrupted broadcasts, slow TV programs offer what film scholar Helen Wheatley calls the “unspectacular' spectacle” of ordinary events occurring in real time.

questions.correct: An example of the slow TV genre can be seen in Nordlandsbanen: Minutt for Minutt, a 2012 Norwegian show featuring an uninterrupted 10-hour real-time broadcast of a train ride from Trondheim to Bodo.

questions.article:
While researching a topic, a student has taken the following notes:

  • Calida Garcia Rawles is an African American painter.
  • She is known for her large-scale, hyperrealistic paintings depicting African American figures in water.
  • The painting Lightness of Being (24 x 30 in) depicts a young man with his arms outstretched floating on the right side of the canvas.
  • Lost in the Shuffle (36 x 24 in) depicts two young men with their arms outstretched floating in the bottom left and upper right corners of the canvas.
  • She paints the water with vivid blue colors, including periwinkle and cobalt.
  • The mood in the paintings is placid.
questions.question: Which choice most effectively uses information from the given sentences to emphasize the location of the figures in Lost in the Shuffle?

options.name: A
options.content: While the number of figures may differ, constant among Rawles's hyperrealistic works is the placid mood that the paintings evoke.

options.name: B
options.content: In Rawles's painting Lost in the Shuffle, two young men are depicted in the bottom left and upper right corners of the canvas.

options.name: C
options.content: At 36 by 24 inches, Rawles's Lost in the Shuffle is even larger than the sizable 24-by-30-inch painting Lightness of Being.

options.name: D
options.content: Rawles captures the water in paintings such as Lightness of Being and Lost in the Shuffle in vivid hues of periwinkle and cobalt.

questions.correct: In Rawles's painting Lost in the Shuffle, two young men are depicted in the bottom left and upper right corners of the canvas.

questions.article:
While researching a topic, a student has taken the following notes:

  • Jean-Michel Basquiat was an American artist who produced more than two thousand drawings and paintings.
  • Most of his works were completed in New York City in the 1980s.
  • His work Mater was completed in 1982.
  • The work is composed of acrylic and oil stick on canvas and measures 72 inches by 84 inches.
  • Mater was purchased by a private collection for $5.8 million in a 2009 auction.
questions.question: Which choice most effectively uses information from the given sentences to emphasize the scope of Basquiat's work?

options.name: A
options.content: Mater is just one of more than two thousand drawings and paintings completed by American artist Jean-Michel Basquiat.

options.name: B
options.content: Though artist Jean-Michel Basquiat completed most of his two thousand-plus drawings in the 1980s, his work Mater is composed of acrylic and oil stick on canvas.

options.name: C
options.content: At a 2009 auction, artist Jean-Michel Basquiat's Mater, composed of acrylic and oil stick on canvas, sold for $5.8 million.

options.name: D
options.content: Decades after artist Jean-Michel Basquiat completed his 1982 work Mater, a private collection purchased it for $5.8 million.

questions.correct: Mater is just one of more than two thousand drawings and paintings completed by American artist Jean-Michel Basquiat.
